roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll resume arguments in Doran against Salem Inn.
Mr. Kassner.
Thank you Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
I think that initially I should review the facts which were scantly reviewed yesterday because there seems to be some misapprehension as to what actually took place.
Appellees herein where owners and operators of premises in which food and liquor was served; one for a period of eight years, one for a period of five years and one for a period of about two years.
At the time the town of North Hempstead passed its ordinance, during that period, they had offered their patrons topless dancing entertainment.
The ordinance forbade the appearance in any public place and underlying any public place of a person with the breast uncovered or with the lower part of the torso uncovered.
This was the broadest imaginable prohibition, it covered every place in the town of North Hempstead and it specifically covered any scene, sketch, act, or entertainment.
In that regard, it was clearly affecting a theatrical performance presumptively protected by the First Amendment.
Now, to -- [Voice Overlap] -- it wasn't covering anything but live people.
Okay.
The appellees did not offer entertainment by a way of topless waitresses.
They did not offer topless bartenders.
What they had was, a real stage, segregated from the patrons on which professional dancers were employed throughout the day to offer dancing entertainment.
These professional dancers were hired through theatrical agencies.
Some of them were employed in ballet work in the City of New York and did this to earn extra money.
This wasn't a situation of -- which was alluded to in LaRue I believe to (Inaudible) in a place it served liquor.

Now, the appellants herein maintain in page 12 their brief the method exercised by the legislative body to ensure the health, safety and well-being of the community is not a proper subject for review by this Court.
I don't know whether they're serious or not serious in that contention but it would seem that the statute was enacted.
The ordinance was enacted under this theory.
It seems that they denied the existence of a supremacy clause.
They claim that they could undercut the evils, various nuisance evils at the source by passing this type of an overbroad speech inhibiting ordinance.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Kassner, am I right in thinking that your claim is basically one of overbreadth that is that New York could have prohibited these particular performances in institutions serving liquor had it drawn an ordinance to that effect?

Had the state liquor authority in the State of New York drawn an ordinance as sanctioned under LaRue involving the licensee, the sale of liquor in premises where this type of activity went on, yes they could've done so Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you say the state liquor authority but you went into federal court to challenge this provision.

We don't know whether New York, we know that New York has this power under the Twenty-first Amendment, we don't know whether it resides in the state liquor authority or whether it's delegated at the town of Hempstead.
I think you pretty well have waived that by failing to litigate that in the state courts.
Well, Your Honor I haven't litigated that here, I don't think I need it.

I'll stick with my overbreadth and I'm just mentioning as an aside that the town of North Hempstead wouldn't have had the power to legislate the type of LaRue ordinance which is permissible but that is not necessary for the purpose of --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why not?
Because --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It isn't regulating liquor is just saying there won't be any nude dancing in bars.
That's not what they've said in this ordinance You Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I know but let's assume they did.
They had a local ordinance so there shall be no nude dancing in any place for liquors so is that what you say -- that's not within the power of municipality?
Yes, Your Honor.
Not within the power of the town of North Hempstead.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's what you're saying?
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is that an issue before us?
No Your Honor.
But that's -- if you asked that's what I'm saying, yes, that's what I'm saying but that's not issue before here Your Honor.
They didn't say no topless dancing in the town of North Hempstead.
They didn't say no topless dancing where liquor was sold in the town of North Hempstead.
They said, No exposure of the breast or the lower part of the torso in the town of North Hempstead in any public place, whether it'd be part of a sketch, scene, act, or entertainment or otherwise.
So, I'm willing to deal with what they did say rather than what they didn't say and I'm not depending upon the fact that they couldn't have passed the LaRue type statute.

There is a contention by Mr. Darago made yesterday that the overbreadth adjudication is limited to the spoken word and all I need to say is that overbreadth adjudication is limited to expression protected by the First Amendment and or presumptively protected by the First Amendment or expression which could be protected by the First Amendment and that includes a great deal more than the spoken work.
He claims that the ordinance was aimed at the elimination of litter, noise, traffic congestion and unspecified conduct of patrons adjacent to appellees premises by a cutting-off at the source.

It should be noted that there are ample laws in the State of New York to cover those evils of litter, noise, traffic congestion, and whatever unspecified conduct of patrons they maybe referring to that if there weren't adequate laws in the State of New York or the town of North Hempstead, these evils could've been cope with by a more narrowly drawn specifically directed piece of legislation rather than what is referred to as a cutting off at the source.

It would be just as appropriate for a town to forbid sporting events because of the traffic congestion incident to a stadium or to forbid political rallies because of the congestion incident to the area where it take place as it is to pass this type of ordinance to cope with traffic congestion or noise or litter.
There is no doubt of what the intention of the town of North Hempstead was.
What I am arguing here today under the doctrine of overbreadth is that the law which they passed was far too broad to be permitted under the First Amendment.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Are you going to get the request Mr. Kassner whether in any event this Court should've proceeded with the suit libel tendency before its judgment of criminal prosecution against one of these three bars?
If you want me to move to that Mr. Justice Brennan, I'll move to that --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That question is here.
Yes, Your Honor.
I was going to --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You're maybe right at everything but wouldn't be immaterial I think if both the District Court shouldn't have preceded with the suit.
On the issue of abstention, we have here two plaintiffs.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, is this abstention, how do you --
Well I'm using abstention in Younger versus Harris sense is that --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is that abstention.
Well Your Honor--

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's alright.
I don't blame you, I don't know that any of us knows.

I've read you a decision in Steffel and I've read your decision in Dombrowski -- all I can say is that I am willing to assume that the Younger doctrine is classified as abstention despite the fact that the Pullman doctrine was classified as abstention and there are two different facets of an abstention issue if you don't want me to use the word abstention, I'll use comedy --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Let's use the Younger doctrine.
The Younger doctrine, yes.

As far as I can tell from my reading of Younger, the holding in Younger was that we're at the time of the filing of a federal suit, the federal plaintiff was then at that time a defendant and a pending criminal proceeding in a single pending criminal proceeding.
The federal court would not take the case and send it back for adjudication in the state criminal proceeding.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, it would dismiss.
Yes Your Honor,It would dismiss.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Just send it back.
It would dismiss.
Now we have two plaintiffs here who where never involved in a pending state criminal prosecution either before or after the commenced to the federal action.
Now, as to them it appears clear that Younger does not apply.
Now, I will get to this argument of privity later but under your decisions in Roe versus -- I think Wade, Roe versus Wade.
You have the same idetical situation of one man who was involved in a state criminal prosecution and one man who wasn't it was dismissed as to the one who was.
The Court took jurisdiction and the term to the question to the one who doesn't.
So, I don't this is a noble issue in this case.
I think that the only issue trully in this case substantive or procedurals is how do you treat M & L?
I dont think there's any question as to the other two plaintiffs on the substantive or procedural issues.

So if you want me to go to how do you treat M & L and why do you treat M & L that way, I will and attack the heart of what I believe is the only problem left in this case after your decision is obvious of production.
Not M & L after the commencement of the federal case violated the statute and were subjected to immediate prosecution.

I will get back to the fact that they were subjective to eight criminal prosecutions at the period of four or five days later and bring that back under the Younger doctrine but right now I'll assume that they had been subjected to a single criminal prosecution in the State Court after the commencement and the file of the federal action by the filing of a federal complaint.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do I understand that the criminal prosecution followed by a day in the following in the filing of the federal complaint?

Yes, the first criminal prosecution followed a day by the filing of a federal complaint because they started violating the ordinance the day after the federal complaint was filed and the motion for the temporary restraining order was denied.
That particular plaintiff, M & L, did not have the staying power of the other two.

It was a question of economics, they were being destroyed and they couldn't accept this destruction of their business in the interim period that would take to determine either the federal or the state action.
They therefore determined to go ahead and do it on the theory that what they were doing would be vindicated in the end.
The question is who should vindicate what they were doing the State Court or the Federal Court.

Now, Judge Oakes in his decision below wrote approximately a page and a half on this on the considerations of treating M & L differently or the same as the other two plaintiffs and frankly I can't improve on either his words or his reasoning and it would be foolish for me to try.
He specified certain consideration which dictated that M & L should be treated the same as the other two plaintiffs.
Now, with the other two plaintiffs, you had no problem, he just said that it is not Younger case and he pass on from that.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Neither the other two plaintiffs ever was prosecuted in the state courts during the -- during any dependency of the federal --
Never Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Litigation.
Yes, never.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that's because I gather they complied with your --
Yes Your Honor.
That is correct.
They had the staying power to be able to do so.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: With M & L did -- have they still, what are they doing now?
M & L is still doing topless dancing.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And where is the state prosecution as of right now?
Waiting for this Court's determination.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And so you -- you represent them in the state composite?
I do Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, you have the case going in the State Court and the Federal Court altogether.
Well, the state court has not proceeded at all.
It's remaining right where it was the date that they were arrested.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's what you were driving forward to get state court among it.
Well, I wasn't driving to get the state, excuse me.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, why did they violate the law?
They violated the law --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The state got the move.
They violated the law which they believed was unconstitutional because they believe they would be out of business before either court adjudicated the issue Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, well you do want it and one of the other courts?
Well, and if the issue was adjudicated in the Federal Court --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In one of the other or not?
Yes Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You wanted one of the other?
Yes Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Or both?
No.
One of the other preferably the Federal Court because that's quicker.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Aren't you running right into Younger?
I don't believe I'm running into Younger.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is it about now?
If M & L were the only --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If you have two court proceeding going at the same time --
Well --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: On the same point.
The question becomes who initiated the second court proceeding?
At the time of the filing of federal complaint, the local authorities will put on notice that there is a substantial federal question involved in the ordinance.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But the temporary restraining order was denied.
Yes Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In the
Federal Court?
Yes Your Honor.
The temporary restraining order was denied.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The difference you have now have an injunction against the enforcement of that criminal proceeding?
Yes Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did you get that from the Court of Appeals?
I got that first from the District Court, it was upheld by the Court of Appeals.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Got it from the second district judge that you went to, was that not?
So you went to Judge Dooling first?
Judge Dooling was an emergency judge.
The case was assigned to Judge Bartels.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: And it went to Bartels and Bartels entered the restraining order, did he not?
It's after a hearing and after about 20 or 30 days after reading briefs and after a hearing, he entered a preliminary injunction.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: it's an injunction which has stop criminal proceeding, isn't it?
The criminal proceeding for all intensive purposes was stopped as soon as it was initiated.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You mean the state didn't proceed with it?
The state did no proceed with it, there was no intention --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But now they can't without violating any --
No.
They can't without violating the federal injunction.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What was the terms of the injunction?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This was a preliminary injunction.
Yes Your Honor.
The terms of the injunction whether the state was in the -- defendants were enjoined from enforcing the ordinance.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Against anybody?
Against these three plaintiff.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Against anybody or not?
As far as I know, against these three plaintiffs.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well didn't they hold it than --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: As far as you know, having you got the injunction, where is the injunction.
Is it in the appendix?
Yes it's in the jurisdictional state -- Page 23(a) of the jurisdictional statement.
Just the plaintiffs --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But if the ordinance is primary declared was the District Court and affirmed by the Court of Appeals was declared unconstitutional on its face, was it not?
The Court of Appeals said that there was a likelihood of success.
They did not declare it unconstitutional as they couldn't because it was merely a preliminary injunction.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what's at the top of page 23(a)?

Well, 23(a) is the District Court, I'm talking about the Circuit Court now and in Appendix 4(a), Judge Oakes' decision says initially, in answer to the question of the propriety of the injunctive relief granted here, we agreed with the District Court as to the probability of success on the merits.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, was that about 16 to 17 lines history for the citation to burn, what about that sentence?
As such the ordinance would have to fall that describes the ordinance as if as such that ordinance would have to fall.
Your Honor, I think he meant to make this final determination in their preliminary injunction motion.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, certainly the District Court at the top of page 23(a) says in conclusion, we find that Local Law No. 1-1973, the town of Hempstead is on its phase violative of plaintiff's First Amendment Rights, that's no suggestion that they may, will very well succeed, that's a flat statement.
That is correct.
But I don't think you can attribute that to Judge Oakes' decision.
That is clear but Judge Oakes' decision is not that clear, he seems to say probability of success and use those words in the proper context for the proper purpose.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Furthermore, are you suggesting that the affirmants do not include what Mr. Justice Rehnquist just read to you, is that it?
Yes Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: But his--but what Judge Oakes says is we agree with the District Court as to the probability of success on the merits.
It construed the District --
(Inaudible)
What it construed, the District Court's opinion as being one of probability of success, that's what it amounts to which is zero.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I think -- you can -- the District Court of Appeals maybe narrow in planning and (Inaudible) --
No Your Honor.
I don't think anybody is damage.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Then what is your right on the probability of -- on eight probabilities there.
Yes Your Honor, I don't --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'll follow the --
I don't think anybody is damage by that.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well the state is pretty (Inaudible) there, if he'd understood that if it did not enforced this ordinance against anybody because of the declaration of unconstitutionality with that as precisely what Mayo against Herington in this court was designed to do that.
But I don't -- those aren't the words he used in his declaration on page 23(a).

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you declared unconstitutional on its face.
Well didn't enter an injunction against every decision.
That is correct.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But more important what you declared unconstitutional on its face and most of the prosecutors until it's finally settled which I will work on of course you are against anybody.
They aren't forcing it against anybody in this -- I don't know --
Well, I think at that time, these were the only three that were doing the activity in the town.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well they --
The activity of topless dancing.
So, they had all the parties before them in my impression.
These role -- the people could've been covered by these all three came into Court together, there was no class action because you had everybody to start out with.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: What more would -- what more remained to be done before Judge Bartels after his order of September 6?
I think something was done -- well, no, an appeal was taken.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: But I mean, he says therefore pending the final determination of this action but what more remained to be done after he had found the ordinance unconstitutional on its phase.
I guess they would have to file an answer and I would have to make a motion for summary judgment.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: But that was all pro forma after this determination, wasn't it?

Well, if you take his words to mean that this was not to be found a probability of success sufficient to warrant an injunction, if you assume that that's not what he meant when he said, what he said, then he would undoubtedly follow his prior determination on the motion for summary judgment but certainly did end the case, you had to do something.
There would have to be motion for summary judgment after he joined the revision, there would have to be a permanent injunction entered and there could've been new facts brought out.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: What if nobody did anything after the order of September 6?
Then it simply remains in status quo idea.

Well, somebody had to file an answer to -- somebody had to make a motion for summary judgment in order to bring it to an end if there wouldn't have been an appeal for the Circuit Court on the preliminary injunction.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, but if nothing is done, Judge Bartels' temporary injunction remains in effect these town as enjoined and it can go on that way I take for 20 years.
Yes, If nothing is done, that would be effect of any preliminary injunction.
It wouldn't be unusual.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I gather your suggestion Mr. Kassner, Judge Oakes at least was conscious of the problem raised by Mayo was he?
Yes Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He did side it.
He didn't side it but Judge Oaks a good judge and he knew what he was doing when he wrote probability of success.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If he did, why did he write as is to the Court in which it would have to fall?
That's a little inconsistent, isn't it?
Sometimes, you --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, at least the issue would be clearer if he had not used that sentence, would it not?
Yes, it would, but I don't think that that should be made to overwrite the words probability of success which are absolutely clear.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Probably, (Inaudible) said, the District Court said that he probably use the sense at zero.
(Inaudible)
Well, if you want to --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Probability of success is 100%.

Well, if you want to construe Judge Oakes meaning that, I don't construe his meaning that because he wasn't asked called unto rule on that and he was called unto rule on probability of success, he used the words probability of success, he meant that the statute was overbroad in his mind at that point, there was a probability of success because of the apparent overbreadth of the statute and by not sticking in the word apparent or I don't know whether you can make his opinion be a final determination or motion for preliminary injunction.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well any of that Mr. Kassner, you going to get neither the question whether because you got into the federal court first that takes care of the Younger problem and even in the M & L or whether would it --
M & L.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: M & L?
Yes.
All as I said before, on this point, all I'm going to do is merely restate what Judge Oakes said because I can improve on it.
He spoke about equity principles granting relief to two people in the same shoes as a third person with respect towards --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's your case but suppose we didn't have the other two parties, all we have was M & L?
I'd be in trouble.
Yes I would.
Because, I don't think I should be but I know that I would be --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You don't think that --
I don't think I should be, no.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If you won the race to the courthouse door by getting in the Federal Court --
I think that should determine it because I think that that's the only reasonable fixed way to determine jurisdiction.
The state courts are no more entitled to adjudicate First Amendment Rights in the Federal Court.
I could make an excellent argument for the fact that the federal court is the prime court for the adjudication of constitutional rights.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well it could (Inaudible)
I don't know whether I'd lose that argument.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: (Inaudible)
No and Younger is an exception to that.

Younger is an exception to that because of doctrines of committee but there is no committee involved to remove Federal Court jurisdiction what's the Younger problem itself does not arise and the Younger problem is a pending criminal prosecution of the federal plaintiff at the time of the filing of a federal complaint.
That's what Younger says.
Now, I was disturbed by Younger but Younger is the law and that is the law.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And look at --
I'm willing to live with Younger but I don't want to see Younger expanded to --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And you could be Younger, you won the race to the courthouse.
Excuse me Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Looking at Younger, you won the race --
Yes I did, yes I did.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You first told your clients you better bide by this ordinance.
I did.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Then you ran into the Federal Court.
And continued to tell them --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Wait a minute, and then you said no, we got to get in the State Court too so you go violate the law now where you give them State Court.
And that had been an added multi court around you to go in that so.
No Judge Marshall, you know I didn't do that --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Then go to North Hempstead.
You know I didn't do that.
Why did I want to create a Younger type problem?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you didn't go to the Admiralty Court, I agree.
I advise all three of my clients to obey the ordinance at least pending the preliminary injunction determination.
Two of my clients followed my instructions; the third client said he couldn't take it.
(Inaudible)
Well, the denial of a TRO is not in adjudication of anything under merits.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: They're in very good shape.

I know that -- that al three would've violated the ordinance as it was written but I didn't and I told them not to violate the ordinance and two obeyed and one didn't and the one didn't because of economic exigencies.
He couldn't stay in business with the cut on business and that's why he had to go about it.
Now, as long as we're talking Younger, why don't we talk about eight prosecutions in a period of three or four days?

Now, Younger clearly held, there is no suggestion that this single prosecution against Harris is brought in bad faith or as only one of a series of repeated prosecutions to which you will be subjected.
I don't think Younger applies if he would've been subjected in a prosecution before he filed his federal complaint.
I don't think the Younger case anyway.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's a harassment exception.
Yes Your Honor.
I mean, Younger is clear on that point.
They serve three summonses, then they had five arrests and they closed the premises on four separate occasions

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you thinks that's -- do you think that's true even though a TRO is denied and even though that the substantial issue about the preliminary injunction.
Well, the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What's the state suppose to do, (Inaudible) rush to the federal court for enforcing its federal laws?
They had this going on for eight years before.
They could've waited 10 or 20 days.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: My question is what do you suppose -- the state prosecutor supposed to do?
Stay its hand until the judge determines the issue in the federal court.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: (Inaudible) he files federal complaint, he supposed to put enforce and laws, is that it?
It depends on what law you're talking about Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We're talking about this one.

Well if I were the -- if I were the local prosecutor and I saw that there was a substantial federal question involved in the ordinance, I might wait the 10 or 15 days that it would take the federal district judge to adjudicate the issue and not quite create the abrasion that they themselves are complaining about.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I understand you -- I am understanding your point, what about your point.
We'll just give way to --
My client should've waited.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And what adjudicate it -- what would he had done at the preliminary injunction has been denied.
He would've been in more trouble than he was with the granting of the preliminary injunction and what would he have done? He might have continued, he might have stopped.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What was the prosecutor suppose to do?
The prosecutor under the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The final adjudication?
No, Your Honor.

After a determination of the preliminary injunction hearing -- on hearings and on briefs, if it was determined that that should not be granted then I don't think the prosecutor is bound to wait any additional time but I think that he could've waited the 10 or 15 days that the rule have taken to avoid this abrasion that he complains about himself but I don't justify my client' conduct.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you Mr. Kassner.
Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
